name: Western Movies
description: Legendary quotes from the Wild West, featuring outlaws, heroes, and frontier justice.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: Go ahead, make my day.
quotes.notes: Often misremembered as from Dirty Harry. Actually from the fourth film. Reagan quoted it addressing Congress.

quotes.content: A man's got to know his limitations.
quotes.notes: Harry's closing line in the second Dirty Harry film. Eastwood's character became a cultural icon.

quotes.content: When you have to shoot, shoot. Don't talk.
quotes.source: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)
quotes.notes: Tuco's practical advice after shooting a bounty hunter. Leone's spaghetti western masterpiece.

quotes.content: You see, in this world there's two kinds of people, my friend: those with loaded guns and those who dig.
quotes.source: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)
quotes.notes: The Man With No Name's ultimatum at the cemetery. Ennio Morricone's score elevated the scene.

quotes.content: I'm your huckleberry.
quotes.notes: Doc's response to Johnny Ringo's challenge. Kilmer's performance became the definitive Holliday.

quotes.content: You're a daisy if you do.
quotes.notes: Doc's sardonic challenge. 'Daisy' was period slang for something special or noteworthy.

quotes.content: I have not yet begun to defile myself.
quotes.notes: Doc's response when told he's drunk. Plays on John Paul Jones' 'I have not yet begun to fight.'

quotes.content: Skin that smoke wagon and see what happens.
quotes.notes: Wyatt challenging a cowboy to draw. Russell's performance balanced toughness with vulnerability.

quotes.content: You tell 'em I'm coming, and hell's coming with me!
quotes.notes: Wyatt's declaration of vengeance after Morgan's death. One of the film's most intense moments.

quotes.content: A man who doesn't spend time with his family can never be a real man.
quotes.notes: Though set in 20th century, shares themes with westerns. Brando's iconic performance won the Oscar.

quotes.content: Fill your hands, you son of a bitch!
quotes.notes: Rooster's challenge before his famous one-man charge. Wayne won his only Oscar for this role.

quotes.content: Courage is being scared to death but saddling up anyway.
quotes.notes: Often attributed to Wayne though not from a specific film. Captures his screen persona's philosophy.

quotes.content: A man ought to do what he thinks is right.
quotes.notes: Wayne's character expressing frontier moral code. One of his personal favorite films.

quotes.content: Out here, due process is a bullet.
quotes.notes: Rooster explaining frontier justice. Reflects the lawless nature of the Old West.

quotes.content: We deal in lead, friend.
quotes.notes: Vin explaining his profession. American remake of Kurosawa's Seven Samurai.

quotes.content: I ain't got time to bleed.
quotes.notes: Though not a western, the line became iconic. Ventura later used it in his political career.

quotes.content: It's a hell of a thing, killing a man. Take away all he's got and all he's ever gonna have.
quotes.notes: Munny's reflection on violence. Eastwood's deconstruction of his own Western legend.

quotes.content: Deserve's got nothing to do with it.
quotes.notes: Munny's response before shooting Little Bill. Rejects moral justification for killing.

quotes.content: I've killed women and children. I've killed everything that walks or crawls at one time or another.
quotes.notes: Munny admitting his violent past. Subverts the noble gunslinger myth.

quotes.content: I reckon so.
quotes.notes: Mattie's practical response. Steinfeld received an Oscar nomination for her debut role.

quotes.content: There are two kinds of spurs, my friend. Those that come in by the door, and those that come in by the window.
quotes.source: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)
quotes.notes: Tuco explaining his approach to life. Wallach stole scenes from his co-stars.

quotes.content: If you want to call me that, smile.
quotes.notes: Cooper's warning to Trampas. From the first sound western to win major acclaim.

quotes.content: A gun is a tool, no better or no worse than any other tool.
quotes.notes: Shane's philosophy about weapons. The film became a template for later westerns.

quotes.content: Sometimes you eat the bear, and sometimes the bear eats you.
quotes.notes: The Stranger's cowboy wisdom in the Coen Brothers' comedy. Elliott embodies western archetype.

quotes.content: This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.
quotes.source: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962)
quotes.notes: Newspaperman's commentary on myth-making. Encapsulates how western legends are created.

quotes.content: Get three coffins ready.
quotes.authorName: The Man with No Name (Clint Eastwood)
quotes.notes: Before Eastwood's first major shootout. He corrects himself: 'My mistake. Four coffins.'

quotes.content: People scare better when they're dying.
quotes.authorName: The Man with No Name (Clint Eastwood)
quotes.notes: Manco's cold observation. The second film in Leone's Dollars Trilogy.

quotes.content: I call that bold talk for a one-eyed fat man.
quotes.notes: Pepper insulting Rooster Cogburn before their confrontation. Duvall in an early role.

quotes.content: Hasta la vista, baby.
quotes.notes: Though sci-fi, uses western farewell styling. Became one of Schwarzenegger's signature lines.

quotes.content: We rob banks.
quotes.notes: Clyde's matter-of-fact introduction. The film revolutionized violence in American cinema.
